Award.AwardTitle: EARS: Collaborative Research: Let's share CommRad -- spectrum sharing between communications and radar systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2012 report to the President entitled "Realizing the Full Potential of Government-Held Spectrum to Spur Economic Growth" recommends releasing portions of the large governmental radar bands to be shared with commercial wireless services. This proposal identifies viable sharing mechanisms between radar and communication systems, which traditionally are operated on non-overlapping bands and are engineered to attain very different goals, so that they may co-exist in a way that is minimally harmful, or ideally beneficial, to both. This research first examines the impact unaltered radar and communication systems would have on one another and thereafter proposes a series of solutions for co-existence that range from realistic solutions with respect to legacy systems (where one of the radar or communication systems remains unaltered) to novel transformative joint designs. The availability of proven robust and optimal sharing mechanisms will pave the way to the development of new wireless services while preserving the critical roles radar systems play in the globally networked society.

A multidisciplinary team with expertise in radar and statistical signal processing, cognitive radio and spectrum sharing, communication and information theory, and electromagnetics and propagation, has been assembled to address the following thrusts: 1) understand and model the impact of overlapping frequency bands on current, unaltered radar and communication systems; 2) a radar centric approach, where adaptive radar processing is the key to reduce interference from communication systems; 3) a communication network centric approach, where coding is used to improve resilience to radar interference; 4) the joint design of communication and radar systems, where the information-theoretic understanding of the tradeoffs between communication data rates and estimation rates is at the base of this cooperative design; 5) validation of the models and proposed algorithms by using real experimental data. The results of this research will be timely presented at major national and international professional venues; the general public will be reached by means of modern social media, such as videos of undergraduate-run experiments that demonstrate the developed technology and its practical impact. The developed fundamental framework will form a solid foundation for spectrum sharing between radar and communication systems; the developed technology is expected to be of immediate and far-reaching use for both radar and communication private and public sectors alike. Students involved in this research will receive a cutting edge education and training in radar and communication sciences, acquiring fundamental skills to be successful in the current competitive, diverse, and global workforce market.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of this research are: (1) to model the effects of interference generated by communication systems on radar system performance; and (2) To develop adaptive radar receiver signal processing techniques to reduce the effects of communication system interference on radar system performance.

 To address the first major goal, we developed new models for communication systems interference and used them to evaluate both fixed-threshold and cell-averaging CFAR radar detectors. These models were motivated by empirical studies that showed a significant decrease in detection probability in CFAR detectors when communication system interference was present, even at power levels 0 to 6dB below the system noise floor. Early studies of radar/communication system coexistence argued by the central limit theorem that for a sufficiently large number of low-power communication transmitters, the interference would appear to be Gaussian noise. If the Gaussian interference model is accurate and the interference power is near the system?s Gaussian noise floor, it was assumed that the interference would not significantly effect the radar system performance. However, experimental testing by the National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) showed that wireless interference behaved very differently than Gaussian noise and negatively effected radar performance, even with interference levels 6 dB below the Gaussian noise floor.

We hypothesized that the cyclostationary nature of these signals was causing the CFAR processor to increase the detection threshold in a way that decreased target detection performance. However, there was no existing analytical work that showed this. So we developed statistical interference models and analyzed their effect on radar detection performance. In particular, we found:

 1. Although multiuser interference may converge to Gaussian statistics conditioned on a fixed large number of sources, when one averages over random path loss effects induced by random transmitter locations, heavy-tailed interference statistics can result. 

 2. In the presence of fast varying non-Gaussian interference, the cell-averaging CFAR detector can have a highly varying false-alarm rate.

 3. The behavior of the Cell-averaging CFAR processor varies significantly with the coherence time (fast or slow variation) of the interference.

 4. The cell-averaging CFAR processor is susceptible to insidious drops in probability of detection at relatively low interference-to-noise rations (INRs), without a corresponding increase in the probability of false alarm. This means that in the presence of low-power-level non Gaussian interference, the cell-averaging CFAR processor can significantly loose it's ability to detect targets, and yet there is no indication (e.g., in terms of increased false alarm rate) that this is happening. 

 A detailed report of these results can be found in journal paper [1] and David P. Zilz's Purdue University Ph.D dissertation [3]. 

To address the second major goal of this research, we developed a novel, temporal signal processing algorithm for a radar to mitigate interference from cyclostationary, linearly-modulated, digital communication interference (LMDC), such as OFDM or CDMA. 

Based on the role of cyclostationary interference in the results of the first major goal of this research, an interference cancellation algorithm consisting of a new cyclostationary whitening filter followed by a matched filter was developed developed to maximize the statistical deflection among the class of all linear detection filters. When compared to the standard stationary interference whitening filter and canceler, the new cyclostationary canceler can have as large as a 20 dB increase in deflection for a single interferer with an INR of 30 dB. However, as the number of  interferers increases, the performance improvement of the cyclostationary whitener over the stationary whitener decreases, so that for a large number of interferers, the performance is nearly identical. So in situations where the near-far problem can exist for interferers and one or two interferers dominate, there can be a significant improvement in overall SINR by using the new cyclostationary whitener. We note also that the performance of the cyclostationary whitener depends on the shape of the waveform used by the communicating interferers, so this suggests that coordinated design of the secondary user communication waveforms can improve radar detection performance.

Significant details of the development of the cyclostationary interference canceler and the proofs of its optimality can be found in journal paper [2] as well as David Zilz's Ph.D dissertation [3].

 

References:

1. David P. Zilz and Mark R. Bell, "Statistical Modeling of Wireless Communications Interference and it's Effects on Adaptive-Threshold Radar Detection," IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems, vol. 54, no. 2, April 2018.

2. David P. Zilz and Mark R. Bell, "Optimal Linear Detection of Signals in Cyclostationary, Linearly-Modulated, Digital Communication Interference," submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems, Dec. 2018, revised July 2018.

3. David P. Zilz, Modeling and Mitigation of Wireless Communication Interference for Spectrum Sharing with Radar, Purdue University Ph.D Dissertation, May 2018.
